message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of recurrent bacterial infections and undetectable serum immunoglobulins suggests Bruton agammaglobulinemia, which is an X-linked disorder that affects boys. Common variable immunodeficiency and DiGeorge syndrome typically present with a wider range of symptoms and are not typically associated with recurrent bacterial infections. Hereditary angioedema is a rare condition that affects the immune system but is not typically associated with recurrent bacterial infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The undetectable levels of all serum immunoglobulins point to a diagnosis of Bruton agammaglobulinemia, an X-linked disorder in which affected individuals cannot produce mature B cells, leading to a lack of immunoglobulins and increased susceptibility to bacterial infections. The family history of similar complaints also suggests a genetic disorder, and this is further supported by the fact that two maternal uncles died from similar complaints. Common variable immunodeficiency and DiGeorge syndrome have different immunological profiles, while hereditary angioedema is not associated with recurrent bacterial infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of recurrent bacterial infections, undetectable serum immunoglobulins, and a family history of similar complaints suggest the most likely diagnosis is Bruton agammaglobulinemia, an X-linked recessive primary immunodeficiency disorder. Common variable immunodeficiency can also present with undetectable serum immunoglobulins, but usually not until later in life. Hereditary angioedema and DiGeorge syndrome do not present with recurrent bacterial infections and undetectable serum immunoglobulins.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A patient with undetectable levels of all serum immunoglobulins suggests that the patient has Bruton agammaglobulinemia, which is an X-linked condition that affects male children. Recurrent bacterial infections and a family history of similar complaints further support this diagnosis. Common variable immunodeficiency and DiGeorge syndrome both have varying levels of immunoglobulins present, while Hereditary angioedema typically presents with swelling rather than recurrent bacterial infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s undetectable serum immunoglobulin levels suggest the diagnosis of Bruton agammaglobulinemia, which is an X-linked recessive disorder that leads to a failure of B-cell maturation and a defect in immunoglobulin production. This disorder usually presents in early childhood and is characterized by recurrent bacterial infections. Common variable immunodeficiency may also present with recurrent infections, but typically has some detectable immunoglobulin levels. Hereditary angioedema is not associated with bacterial infections, and DiGeorge syndrome is a disorder of T-cell development, not B-cell development.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation, family history, and laboratory findings suggest Bruton agammaglobulinemia, which is a genetic disorder characterized by a lack of B cells and absence of immunoglobulins. Common variable immunodeficiency also presents with recurrent infections and low immunoglobulins, but onset is usually later in life. Hereditary angioedema and DiGeorge syndrome do not present with undetectable levels of all serum immunoglobulins.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The recurrent bacterial infections and undetectable levels of serum immunoglobulins suggest that the patient has Bruton agammaglobulinemia, a primary immunodeficiency disorder characterized by failure of B cell differentiation and decreased levels of immunoglobulins. Common variable immunodeficiency may also present with recurrent bacterial infections and low immunoglobulin levels, but it typically has a later onset. Hereditary angioedema is a disorder of the complement system and does not typically present with recurrent bacterial infections. DiGeorge syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects the development of several organs, including the thymus, and can result in immunodeficiency, but it is unlikely to present with recurrent bacterial infections and undetectable immunoglobulin levels alone.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The undetectable level of all serum immunoglobulins suggests Bruton agammaglobulinemia, an X-linked genetic disorder that affects the maturation of B cells, leading to decreased or absent production of immunoglobulins. The family history is also suggestive of an X-linked genetic disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The undetectable level of all serum immunoglobulins suggests Bruton agammaglobulinemia, which is a condition where B cells fail to develop into mature, functional B lymphocytes, resulting in a lack of immunoglobulins. The family history also supports this diagnosis. Common variable immunodeficiency and DiGeorge syndrome typically present with different symptoms and are not strongly associated with recurrent bacterial infections. Hereditary angioedema is not related to immunoglobulin deficiencies.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's undetectable level of all serum immunoglobulins is a classic presentation of Bruton agammaglobulinemia, an X-linked recessive disorder that affects the development of B lymphocytes. The family history of similar complaints suggests a genetic component. Common variable immunodeficiency typically presents in later childhood or adulthood and does not have a clear genetic basis. Hereditary angioedema is characterized by recurrent episodes of swelling but does not affect humoral immunity. DiGeorge syndrome affects thymus development and typically presents with cardiac defects and facial anomalies.
